description: From Latin vernāculus (“domestic, indigenous, of or pertaining to home-born slaves”), from verna (“a native, a home-born slave (one born in his master's house)”).

adjectives.description: vernacular (comparative more vernacular, superlative most vernacular)

entries.meaning: Of or pertaining to everyday language, as opposed to standard, literary, liturgical, or scientific idiom.
examples: Synonyms: common, everyday, indigenous, ordinary, vulgar, colloquial

entries.meaning: Belonging to the country of one's birth; one's own by birth or nature.
(architecture) Of or related to local building materials and styles; not imported.
(art) Connected to a collective memory; not imported.
The language of a people or a national language.
examples: Coordinate terms: lingua franca, link language, vehicular language
A vernacular of the United States is English.

entries.meaning: Everyday speech or dialect, including colloquialisms, as opposed to standard, literary, liturgical, or scientific idiom.
examples: Street vernacular can be quite different from what is heard elsewhere.

entries.meaning: Language unique to a particular group of people.
examples: For those of a certain age, hiphop vernacular might just as well be a foreign language.

entries.meaning: A language lacking standardization or a written form.
Indigenous spoken language, as distinct from a literary or liturgical language such as Ecclesiastical Latin.
examples: Vatican II allowed the celebration of the mass in the vernacular.

entries.meaning: (architecture) A style of architecture involving local building materials and styles, not imported.
